The no does not exist on a fresh install before the device connects to the Internet.  So it is coming from the Internet, and not present in the OS itself.

@chimon1984 @NikantChaudhary @tiagoreisalves @pleerock @igor_randj @jenlooper But I do believe not having runtime reflection will definitely affect mass-acceptance. It will make ORMs and REST mappers less capable. (Code generation creates a mess in the codebase). And that is not good for pretty big apps. Other langs can do tree shaking despite reflection

@chimon1984 @NikantChaudhary @tiagoreisalves @pleerock @igor_randj @jenlooper ... UI that is same across all platforms can actually benefit a *LOT* from the approach like Flutter. 
Not even actual native (Kotlin or Swift) can get the kind of view animation smoothness that Flutter (or Unity) can provide.

@chimon1984 @NikantChaudhary @tiagoreisalves @pleerock @igor_randj @jenlooper Also Flutter is closer to Fuse in not requiring a JS runtime, and also similar to how game renderers like Unity work that has a unique strong point of rendering all the pixels itself. And I can see clearly the appeal in that. Apps like AirBNB or Instagram which have signature ...

@chimon1984 @NikantChaudhary @tiagoreisalves @pleerock @igor_randj @jenlooper P.S. Three of those thousands of commits to Flutter are mine. I'm not against it, but only a certain type of apps possible with it. I am making a production app with it too right now

@chimon1984 @NikantChaudhary @tiagoreisalves @pleerock @igor_randj @jenlooper Not interested in looking at it seriously unless there's reflection support. No ORM, no REST mappers possible without that

I teach programming for the last 2 years, and this is one of the earliest instincts I try to throw out of students' heads. Usually when they come up with errors, I make them read it line by line. And 8/10 times they look back at me smiling realising they have figured it out. https://t.co/j7MeidcIdo

Sometimes tools do not spew out accurate error messages. Some tools show the wrong line while debugging. Some errors are hard to replicate (esp. threading related). BUT ALL THAT SAID, > 90% of time, if you just spent 1 extra minute reading the entire stack trace, you'd get it.

While the internet, and especially Google/Stackoverflow has made learning new technology exponentially easier, it has also propagated a class of very undeserving programmers. 
The reflex action, every moment you see an error, to dump it into Google, is something you need to fight

If you use a game engine that runs on iOS and Android (i.e cross plat at the native level) and use it to render graphics like 'button' and 'text' what you get is a cross platform app platform. This is exactly what Flutter has done.

I started off understanding 'how a programming language works' with only C++ in school.
After that I never went through the motions of "learning a language" with any other language. 
True, I haven't worked with non-C-like languages like Haskell/Lisp though.

This may or may not be a good strategy for others, but since lot of my students ask 'how I did it', the answer is this - 
I didn't learn Java before Android, Swift before iOS, or Javascript before Webdev. 
I came back and spent months understanding the languages later though.

Presenting: Taj Mahal in pitch black darkness 

I am pretty much a noob photographer, and the camera is a hybrid/hyperzoom (Sony HX400v), not a real DSLR. 
But still pretty good capabilities. You might like the photos. 
(See the thread too) https://t.co/KHkWZVZW6a

Wrapping off with some photos that show how Camera basics 101 can help you take photos of objects near invisible to naked eye in extremely low light conditions. 
1: naive photo
2: nearly what naked eye sees
3: camera presets take you here
4: fine-tune manual settings & voila! https://t.co/C2TJk2uYFj

Photo 8: Best frame I could grab. Final step: turn to black and white only mode. CMOS sensors, like our eyes, can capture more detail if they have to only detect brightness, and no color. (We see in b/w when in low light). https://t.co/aPDWNrEPlA

Photo 7: Slightly more #shutterspeed, gets better edges and contrast. Losing a bit of brightness due to #exposure drop. It isn't a silhouette anymore. We see a real 3d @TajMahal emerging. https://t.co/MhixU1Cgyg
#TajMahal #lowlight #nightphotography https://t.co/mtCuICYnT7
#LowLight #Photography #ItWasPitchBlack #HX400V #SONY #LongExposure https://t.co/YOBTGgwtQQ

Photo 6: Zooming in a bit more, to get some more details, crop the foilage and light that is overexposing the bottom right area. The spires are actually legitimate wiry shapes now. https://t.co/x0SlqwS9iA

Retweeted Arnav Gupta (@championswimmer):

Photo 4: After some more experimentation, dropping down ISO to 200 (80... https://t.co/6hqBydPPlV

Photo 5: Slowly going up the exposure scale. Now at 8s. Holding breath to be steady. Damn I miss my tripod dearly. Decreasing the exposure balance. More details emerge, not much color though. https://t.co/c1MnFpdRZB

Photo 4: After some more experimentation, dropping down ISO to 200 (80 is lowest possible, but totally negates the exposure increase). Kneeling down, locking elbows with wall to get 2s exposure. https://t.co/M2bOAQdeKX

Do you see a seamless flow? Or you see friction?  Unless you visualise a elegant end-to-end flow,  don't proceed further with other parts
Every now and then close your eyes and look at the big picture. The user navigating from oage to page.  Data flowing through you APIs.
If every now and then you don't get the feeling "this is exquisite, I can't want for someone to use it", you're not doing it right.
Backends, frontends, visualisations, libraries...  All are products.  Simply consumed by different people (not necessarily end user)
Every few days take a step back and look at your product (API/App/Site/Graph) from the consumers' standpoint. Does it delight you?

@emberjs @Square @LinkedIn @heroku @travisci @intercom @AppleMusic @PlayStation_Now When they say it's built for 'ambitious' webapps, they do actually mean it.
@emberjs It isn't hard to see why @Square, @LinkedIn, @heroku, @travisci, @intercom, @AppleMusic, @PlayStation_Now are built with ember.
When you realise how hard the @emberjs team has worked not *just* on the view, but all needs of a web*APP*, you truly enjoy working with it
Having a data adapter - that consumes an API, caches responses, persists locally, AND also updates seamlessly - smth frameworks just ignore
Among the big 3 (ng, vue, react), no one ever actually thought that in large scale webapps, the MV* act is only a small part of the game
And personally, I really love the way Vue or React have been able to get some really perfect view rendering strategies, they just solve that
While all the frontend frameworks chase that 'perfect' model-view binding API, only ember-data solves the real hard problem of data managmnt
